awd_titl_txt: SCH: EXP: Collaborative Research: Group-Specific Learning to Personalize Evidence-Based Medicine
awd_abstract_narration:
Patient care is increasingly guided by evidence based practice guidelines, which are defined as "systematically developed statements to assist practitioner and patient decisions about appropriate health care for specific clinical circumstances." These guidelines are viewed as the key to improving patient care and reducing costs, but current guidelines tend to be specific to individual diseases, and rarely consider all of the relevant details of a patient's condition, such as age, gender, and ethnic background, as well as other diseases from which patients suffer. By addressing the challenge of personalized evidence based medicine, the research in this project positively impacts patients suffering from multiple chronic conditions, which is becoming the norm in the aging US population.  To that end, this project develops new clinical modeling techniques that can use the data available in electronic health records (EHRs) to improve the personalization of these guidelines. More specifically, the ultimate goal of this project is to generate more personalized guidelines that can be implemented in clinical decision support systems and used by physicians and others for the comprehensive treatment of patients with multiple chronic conditions.

To address the challenge of personalized care guidelines to handle multiple chronic conditions, this project develops a modeling framework, Group-Specific Learning (GSL), with the ability to enhance clinical modeling by making models increasingly personalized without rendering them excessively specific. In particular, the GSL modeling paradigm is applied to enhance four modeling techniques commonly used in health sciences research: survival analysis, causal analysis via propensity scoring, competing risk models and multi-state models. This work focuses on type-II diabetes mellitus (T2DM), its precursor, pre-diabetes, its comorbidities (hypertension, obesity, hyperlipidemia), and its consequences (chronic kidney disease, renal failure and the various cardiac and vascular complications). Diabetes has a number of interrelated comorbidities and severe complications, but evidence-based guidelines for the treatment of these conditions treat these conditions in isolation. To address this limitation, this project develops a suite of analytics techniques that can take the substantial heterogeneity that exists in the diabetic population into account in order to measure the effect of existing evidence-based guideline elements (interventions) in terms of risk of progression to diabetic complications. These guideline elements can then be compiled into guidelines, thus allowing for the systemic and comprehensive treatment of the population with heterogeneity.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This exploratory project included multiple studies to develop algorithms and methods for producing actionable insights from electronic health record (EHR) data from two large Midwestern health settings after institutional review board approval.  Our project focused on developing new modeling techniques that can use the data available in electronic health records (EHRs) to improve the personalization of these guidelines. More specifically, to handle multiple chronic conditions, this project developed a modeling framework, Group-Specific Learning (GSL), with the ability to enhance clinical modeling by making models increasingly personalized without rendering them excessively specific. The primary outcomes of this work were related to creating a disease-specific hierarchy for better describing and modeling the current state of a patient and the development of new approaches to incorporate causal knowledge into the modeling of EHR data. This work focused on type-II diabetes mellitus (T2DM), its precursor, pre-diabetes, its comorbidities (hypertension, obesity, hyperlipidemia), and its consequences (chronic kidney disease, renal failure, and the various cardiac and vascular complications).

 The following describes some of the studies we performed and their results.

 Mining Electronic Health Record: A Survey. In this manuscript, which was published in ACM Computing Surveys, we provide a structured and comprehensive overview of data mining techniques for modeling Electronic Health Record (HER) data. We provided a detailed understanding of the major application areas to which EHR mining has been applied and then discussed the nature of EHR data and its accompanying challenges. We then described major approaches used for EHR mining, the metrics associated with EHRs, and the various study designs. With this foundation, we provided a systematic and methodological organization of existing data mining techniques used to model EHRs and discussed ideas for future research.

Incorporating Causality into EHR Modeling. Our aging population increasingly suffers from multiple chronic diseases simultaneously, necessitating the comprehensive treatment of these conditions. Finding the optimal set of drugs for a combinatorial set of diseases is a combinatorial pattern exploration problem. Association rule mining is a popular tool for such problems, but the requirement of health care for finding causal, rather than associative, patterns renders association rule mining unsuitable. To address this issue, we proposed a novel framework for extracting causal rules from observational data, correcting for a number of common biases. Specifically, given a set of interventions and a set of items that define subpopulations (e.g., diseases), we wish to find all subpopulations in which effective intervention combinations exist, and in each such subpopulation, we wish to find all intervention combinations such that dropping any intervention from this combination will reduce the efficacy of the treatment. To implement our ideas, we introduced and compared five methods of estimating causal effect from observational data and rigorously evaluated them on synthetic data to mathematically prove (when possible) why they work. We also evaluated our causal rule mining framework on the Electronic Health Records (EHR) data of a large cohort of 152000 patients and showed that the patterns we extracted are sufficiently rich to explain the controversial findings in the medical literature regarding the effect of a class of cholesterol drugs on Type-II Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM). This work was published in the IEEE International Conference on Big Data.

 Disease Severity Hierarchy: a novel representation of diseases and treatment pathways for risk stratification: This work resulted in the acceptance of a paper in the JAMA Open Network of the American Medical Association. This paper, co-authored by the Mayo and UMN members of our team, represents the culmination of several years of work. Domain knowledge about diseases and their comorbidities, disease severity, treatment pathways, and outcomes can facilitate diagnosis, enhance preventive strategies, and help create smart, evidence-based practice guidelines. This work introduced a new representation: Disease Severity Hierarchy (DSH), which leverages domain knowledge in a nested fashion to create subpopulations that share increasingly richer amounts of clinical details suitable for risk prediction. This study developed age-specific models to predict all-cause mortality (ACM) and major cardiovascular events (MCE) based on DSH while adjusting for sex and race. The proposed DSH risk scores accurately predicted the age at which a patient is at risk of dying or developing MCE significantly better than standard methods. DSH utilizes known relationships among entities in EHR data to capture disease severity in a natural and clinically meaningful way. Further, DSH is expressive and interpretable. Our novel patient representation can help to support critical decision making, the development of smart guidelines, and enhance chronic disease management by helping to identify high-risk patients. Additionally, DSH has the potential to be used as a healthcare quality metric.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2021
Modified by: Michael S Steinbach
